fate: Service discontinued on 2017-12-15 after usage declines amid mobile and social messaging shifts.
summary: AOL’s pioneering instant-messaging service (Buddy List, away messages) launched in 1997 and shut down in 2017.
overview_md: **AOL Instant Messenger (AIM)** was one of the defining chat clients of the dial-up and early broadband era. Launched in **1997**, it popularized the **Buddy List**, distinctive **screen names**, and the culture of **away messages**. AIM supported 1:1 and group chat and helped normalize real-time presence online. As mobile-first messengers and social apps rose, AIM’s usage fell, and AOL announced the end of the service in **October 2017**, shutting it down on **December 15, 2017**.

timeline.text: AIM launches as a standalone instant-messaging client separate from the AOL desktop.
Peak early-2000s era: Buddy List and away messages become mainstream in the U.S.
Mid-2000s client refresh (“AIM Triton”) introduces a new UI and voice/video features. (Date approximate; keep if you add a strong source.)
AIM organization restructured; product enters a redesign period amid the shift to mobile messaging.
AOL announces AIM will be discontinued.
